ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Became more familiar with modern philosophy of language, especially enjoyed Lock, Berkeley, and Hume
broad survey of philosophy of language in the early modern period

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The material of this class was very challenging, in my opinion, and sometimes the discussion felt dominated by the graduate students taking the course, as thoughtful and kind as they were.
This is a very enjoyable course. However, the fact that one paper makes up 50% of the grade makes that one assignment too high pressure compared to other ones.

the handouts were very well structured, both Prof. Winkler and Prof. Szabo are experts in the field and it was a pleasure learning from them. However, discussion was sometimes derailed and too much time spent on minutiae compromised the discussion time for the more crucial topics that could have been discussed, which was a pity since we only had 1 or 2 classes on each philosopher

Strengths: Both professors were great discussion leaders and very thorough in their answers.
Weakness: The readings and materials covered in a single seminar were sometimes ambitious which made it hard for me digest the material and wrap my mind around the topic.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Great addition of undergraduate chats to make the seminar a little more approachable.
relatively large seminar class meant that it sometimes felt difficult to participate over zoom, but the professors kindly set up an undergrad discussion time which was brilliant

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I highly recommend Prof. Szabo and Prof. Winkler, however, I would caution philosophy students or other undergraduate students from taking the course unless they have a strong established interest in the field; I ultimately struggled to understand the significance of many of the concepts being discussed in class and felt a little discouraged as a result.

Yes, the topic is interesting and the Professor are both fascinating. There is a lot of reading, some of it a bit dry, but it is all very valuable. The lectures really tie everything together and show why the readings matter.
yes!! great chance to delve deeper into the lesser known writings of the early modern thinkers and sets up an interesting context for contemporary philosophy of language as we know it

Yes, if you're ready to read A LOT. Don't be afraid, the professors provide a handout for every class which makes it easier to navigate the material. Also, they're both legends in their areas, no doubt you'll learn a lot.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
